block.p: Strict Shiite Religious Rule Dominates Oil Port in Iraq The once libertine oil port of Basra, 350 miles south of Baghdad and far from the insurgency raging in much of Iraq, is steadily being transformed into a mini-theocracy under Shiite rule.

The group that claims it kidnapped Egypt's top diplomat in Iraq said in an Internet posting that a religious court had condemned him to die and that he had been handed over to fighters to carry out the sentence.

Israel Denies Discord in Gaza The spokesman for Prime Minister Ariel Sharon denied an article published in The New York Times that said Israelis and Palestinians had failed to agree on how to deal with the houses of settlers who will be pulled out of Gaza.

Bush Arrives for G8 Summit President Bush arrived in Scotland for a summit meeting of the big industrial nations after signaling that he would not budge on one of the most contentious issues dividing the United States from its allies, how best to address global warming.

Temple Attack Sparks Protest Police in India fired tear gas at demonstrators in New Delhi who were protesting an attack on a disputed religious site, that has emerged a potent symbol of sectarian strife.

U.S. Balks at Colombian Law Colombia's new law to demobilize paramilitary death squads suffered a blow when lawmakers in Washington threatened to block money President Álvaro Uribe's government needs to put the law into effect.

Prince Albert II Recognizes Heir Prince Albert II of Monaco recognized paternity of a boy born to a former stewardess nearly two years ago, conferring to the boy the rights to a portion of his fortune.

Times Reporter Is Jailed For Keeping Source Secret Judith Miller, a reporter for The New York Times, was sent to jail after a federal judge declared that she was ''defying the law'' by refusing to divulge the name of a confidential source. Matthew Cooper of Time magazine, was spared a prison sentence after announcing a last-minute deal that he said would allow him to testify before a grand jury.
First Hurricane of the Season With fresh memories of last year's barrage of deadly storms, Floridians kept a watchful eye on Hurricane Dennis, the year's first.

New England Fights for Bases Officials from five New England states asked the independent commission analyzing the proposed military-base closings to spare their states, saying the Pentagon used faulty information, inflated savings and incomplete criteria.

Trial on Clean Air Act Opens American Electric Power, the nation's biggest power generating company, broke the Clean Air Act by failing to cut emissions at plants in four states, a federal lawyer argued as the government opened a lawsuit against the utility.

Limbaugh Records Released A Florida judge released medical records of the commentator Rush Limbaugh to prosecutors, allowing them to move forward in an investigation into whether Mr. Limbaugh illegally bought painkillers.

Bush Presses Senate on Court In his most extensive comments to date on the subject, President Bush admonished the Senate not to heed ''the special interest groups, particularly those on the extremes'' as he moves towards a Supreme Court nomination.

Rapper Lil' Kim Sentenced To One Year for Perjury The rapper known as Lil' Kim was sentenced to serve a year and a day in federal prison and pay a $50,000 fine for perjury, after she made a surprise admission that she had lied to a grand jury and again during her trial.

Obstacle for Brooklyn Arena A rival of developer Bruce C. Ratner submitted a competing bid to buy and develop the site of a proposed Nets arena, throwing up the first significant obstacle to Mr. Ratner's plan to create an urban hub at the eastern edge of Downtown Brooklyn.

London Wins 2012 Games In a surprising upset over front-running Paris, London was chosen by the International Olympic Committee to host the 2012 Summer Games. New York, one of the five cities in contention, was knocked out of the race in the second round of voting.
After his hopes of bringing the Olympics to New York collapsed, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged what many others had been saying for several years -- that the bid had been a long shot.
L. Patrick Gray III The former acting director of the F.B.I., whose early missteps in handling the Watergate investigation made him a victim of a scandal he helped expose, he was 88.

Cnooc Head Discusses Unocal The chairman of Cnooc Ltd. faces delicate dual tasks in his company's $18.5 billion bid to buy Unocal -- he must prove his political reliability to Chinese leaders as he works to persuade the United States that his company cares only about commerce.
Health Insurer Acquisition UnitedHealth Group made a big push into the rapidly growing Medicare market by agreeing to buy Pacificare Health Systems for $8.14 billion.

Study Faults Insurers A study to be released by the Center for Justice and Democracy finds that net claims for medical malpractice paid by 15 leading insurance companies have remained flat over the last five years, while net premiums have increased 120 percent.
